Background.text:
Definition: end-organ damage due to hypertension
Blood pressure is generally >180/120 (usually > 220/130), but presence of end-organ damage defines disease (not absolute blood pressure number)
1%-6% of all ED patients will present with severe hypertension, but less than half of those will have target organ damage
[1]

Workup.text:
Consider any of the following based on the patient's clinical presentation
[4]
CBC with peripheral smear- assess for microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
Chem 8 - assess renal failure and possible secondary causes
Cardiac enzymes
Urinalysis
- Assess renal failure, glomerulonephritis, preeclampsia
ECG
-
LVH
,
ischemia
Ultrasound
- evaluate for aortic dissection, bladder outlet obstruction, or depressed myocardial function
Fundoscopic Exam
- evaluate for hypertensive retinopathy or papilledema
CXR
- evaluate for pulmonary edema or dissection
CT head
- in hypertensive encephalopathy, may not show acute hemorrhage or other acute pathology
Hypertensive encephalopathy is thought to be secondary to alteration in cerebral auto-regulation leading to
posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome
(now called reversible posterior leukoencephalopathy). Most patients will show changes on MRI, although this is not necessarily indicated in the emergency department.

Diagnosis.text:
Must have evidence of end-organ dysfunction
High blood pressure without symptoms is NOT hypertensive emergency (see
asymptomatic hypertension
)
Symptoms such as headache, epistaxis and dizziness are not evidence of acute end-organ damage and they are not indication for acute BP reduction

Management.text:
High blood pressure without end organ damage is NOT hypertensive emergency (see
asymptomatic hypertension
)
Goal: Lower mean arterial or systolic pressure by no more than 10-20% in the first hour
[5]
Then lower by an additional 5-15% over the next 23 hours for no more than 25% in the first 24 hours
Exception is
aortic dissection
which requires rapid reduction to systolic BP to 100-120 mmHg
Be careful of lowering BP in patients with
CVA

tables.Dose: 0.3-0.5 mcg/kg/min IV initial infusionIncrease by 0.5 mcg/kg/min up to 2mcg/kg/min
tables.Cons: 1. Cyanide Toxicity2. Coronary steal?3. Increased HR
tables.Notes: 1. Avoid in liver/renal failure2. Avoid with increased ICP3. Avoid in pregnancy
Drug of choice in patients with cardiac ischemia,LV dysfunction, or pulmonary edema

tables.Dose: 20-80mg IV bolus q10 minOR0.5-2 mg/min IV infusion or200mg to 400mg PO BID
tables.Pros:
1. No change in HR, cerebral flow
2. Rapid onset
tables.Cons: Avoid in COPD, CHF and heart block
tables.Notes:
1. Consider in ACS
2. Consider in ischemic CVA

tables.Dose: Load 250-500 mcg/kg over 2minInfuse 50 mcg/kg/min over 4min- if ineffective repeat load, increase infusion rate by  50mcg/kg/min up to 300mcg/kg/min
Start 5mg/hIf ineffective after 15min increased in 2.5mg/hr interval up to 15mg/hr
Bolus 1.25mg over 5min q6hr, titrate at 30min intervals to max of 5mg q6hr
tables.Mechanism: Decreases HR, SV, systemic arterial pressure
tables.Notes: 1. Used in patients at risk for cerebral hypotension, CHF2. Avoid in pregnancy

tables.Dose: 0.1 - 0.3 mg PO q12 scheduled; For hypertensive emergency, 0.2 mg x1, then 0.1 mg q1 hr PRN, max 0.6 mg total
tables.Mechanism: α-2 agonist, BP effects within 30-60 min after PO dose
tables.Notes: Reduced CNS sympathetic flow, decreasing SVR, HR, BP; no renal blood flow changes; tolerance/tachyphylaxis develop quickly

tables.Dose: 10 - 20 mg slow IV/IM bolus q4-6 hr PRN, max 40 mg/dose
tables.Mechanism: Peripheral vasodilator, with fall in BP beginning within 30 min, lasting 2-4 hrs
tables.Notes: Decrease in DBP > SBP; has increased HR, stroke volume and cardiac outpt; preferential vasodilation > venodilation

Aortic_Dissection.text:
Rapidly reduce sys BP to 100-120; HR 60-80 within 20min
Adequate analgesia will decrease sympathetic drive and assist with BP and HR control
Avoid volume depletion
Prevent reflex tachycardia
Labetalol alone
Nitroprusside or nicardipine AFTER metoprolol or esmolol

Pulmonary_Edema.text:
Reduce BP by 20-30%
Promote diuresis AFTER vasodilation

ACS.text:
No more than 20-30% reduction for SBP >160
Consider NTG, beta-blocker

Cocaine/Amphetamine_Toxicitiy.text:
Benzos
Mixed α + B blockade
Phentolamine
OR
nitroprusside AND β-blocker

Renal_Failure.text:
Reduce BP by no more than 20%
Avoid nitroprusside (renal metabolism)
Labetalol or nicardipine

Eclampsia/Pre-eclampsia.text:
Goal BP <160/110
Labetalol or nicardipine
Magnesium

Hypertensive_emergency.text:
Decrease MAP by 15-20%
Avoid overly aggressive lowering
Nicardipine
or
labetalol

If thrombolytic treatment is planned then goal systolic blood pressure 185 mm Hg and diastolic blood pressure 110 mm Hg
[6]
If no thrombolytics then consider blood pressure control if SBP >220 mmHg or DBP >120 mmgHg
Labetalol
or
Nicardipine
are both effective and safe
